ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Occupational Noise-Induced Hearing Loss (NIHL)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: The patient presents with a history of long-term unprotected occupational noise exposure and a bilateral, symmetric high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss with a characteristic 'noise notch' at 3000â€“6000 Hz and recovery at 8000 Hz.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To define the degree, type, and configuration of hearing loss and assess for characteristic noise-induced patterns.

ordered_list.action: Hearing protection device (HPD) fit check and attenuation measurement
ordered_list.rationale_short: To verify if current PPE provides adequate protection against workplace noise levels.
Recommended to quantify current noise exposure levels and ensure OSHA compliance.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Historical records show a progressive decline in high-frequency hearing sensitivity over 30+ years of employment, starting from a normal baseline.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry (Historical)
tests.result_summary: Progressive high-frequency threshold shifts evident from 1971 to 1984, meeting criteria for Standard Threshold Shift (STS).

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Diagnostic findings confirm bilateral, symmetric, high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss with a noise-notch configuration, consistent with NIHL.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Bilateral high-frequency SNHL with notch at 3-6 kHz and recovery at 8 kHz; STS confirmed.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Good word recognition scores (80%) bilaterally but at elevated presentation levels (50-60 dB HL).

tests.name: Immittance & OAEs
tests.result_summary: Type A tympanograms; acoustic reflexes absent at 4000 Hz; DPOAEs absent 2000-6000 Hz, consistent with cochlear damage.

tests.name: HPD Fit Check
tests.result_summary: Field attenuation of foam earplugs measured 15-40 dB depending on frequency; adequate if worn correctly.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Medical evaluation rules out systemic or retrocochlear causes; confirms diagnosis of work-related NIHL.

tests.name: Medical Evaluation
tests.result_summary: Normal otoscopy; negative labs; diagnosis of bilateral SNHL secondary to noise exposure (95% attributed to work).

proposed_items: Process workers' compensation claim for settlement and lifetime hearing health provision.
Continue use of hearing protection devices (HPDs) for all occupational noise exposures.
Recommend electronic hearing protection for recreational firearm use.
counseling_actions: Explain that the hearing loss is permanent and caused by hair cell damage from noise.
Emphasize the critical need to protect remaining hearing at work and during hobbies (hunting).
Discuss realistic expectations for hearing aids, noting good prognosis due to speech recognition scores.
Advise on the lifetime replacement cycle of hearing aids (approx. every 4-6 years).

escalation.rationale_short: To provide medical clearance for hearing aids and formally determine work-relatedness for the compensation claim.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor for any further threshold shifts and assess hearing aid function and benefit.

expected_outcome: Patient reports excellent subjective benefit and acceptance of hearing aids.
Improved communication with family and in meetings.
Successful settlement of workers' compensation claim including financial compensation and lifetime hearing care.
Prevention of further noise-induced loss through consistent HPD use.
